reviewText: For a seventh grader, a good starting point on methods, both traditional and modern, for taking notes for writing.  Does target an older audience but understandable though a little dry.

This DVD offers a fabulous introduction to note-taking for students. It's also a great refresher course for experienced researchers with poor note-taking habits. It reminds viewers of the intimate connection between writing and thinking, and urges us to view note-taking not as mindless transcription, but as a foundation for significant research. In essence, it asks viewers to respect past scholarship by conscientiously reading, quoting, paraphrasing and commenting on it in notes. But it does all this with an eye on instruction. It shows you exactly how to analyze and interpret data and ideas, create a bibliographic database, and cultivate your own note-taking style using an array of techniques from sticky notes and index cards to notebooks and laptops. This DVD also nicely complements The Craft of Research, 2nd edition (Chicago Guides to Writing, Editing, and Publishing), a book that I highly recommend.
